title: PAD2: interactive exploration of transcription factor genomic colocalization using ChIP-seq data
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Accessing PAD2 and select TFs for colocalization analysis
Timing: <5 min
Here we describe the steps to begin the analysis from PAD2, starting with selecting a set of signal files from the database. The selected proteins will be used in targeted colocalization analysis within 12 functional genomic regions identified by ChromHMM.13[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib13]
Open PAD2, from http://pad2.maths.usyd.edu.au/[href=http://pad2.maths.usyd.edu.au/].
Click the “Select signals from the database” button on the side panel (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A) to open a modal page with an interactive data table of files in the database (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2568-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Screenshots of PAD2
(A) The landing page of PAD2 when you access the website.
(B) An example page showing a table of files in the database when you click the “Select signals from the database” button.
Select the signals of TFs and/or histone marks of interest from the database.
You can sort the table by clicking the column names and search for a file using the search bar on the top right corner of the modal page.
Click anywhere on the row of the table to select. The selected rows will be highlighted.
Once all the files of interest are selected, click the “Save” button.
User’s signal file upload (optional).
Click the “Browse…” button on the side panel.
Browse your local computer directory to select all the files you wish to upload.
Click the submit button.
Note: The user’s own signal data submission is optional. If the user only wishes to analyze the files in our database, action 4 can be skipped.
Critical: Access to the website may not be successful in the event of server maintenance or power outages. Please send an email to the administrator for assistance. Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.1].

Critical: The user’s input file must be aligned to mm9 assembly to be compatible with those in the database and in the required format shown in Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] above (See ChIP-seq data preparation from before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]. Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3].
Selecting genomic region of interest and submitting the input form
Timing: minutes to hours
This section describes steps to specify a functional genomic region to analyze the colocalization from the selected set of proteins at the region of interest. The colocalization is assessed by clustering Pearson’s correlation from the user specified ChIP-seq profiles.
Select the functional genomic region of interest from the dropdown menu on the side panel (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2568-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Sidebar options for PAD2
(A) List of functional genomic regions defined by Kim et al.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] using chromHMM.13[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib13] Each functional genomic region and their coverage on the chromatin are shown in the squared brackets.
(B) An optional input form to plot ranked correlation plot.
[Optional] To visualize the ranked correlation of protein of interest by its similar groups, check the “Plot ranked correlation” checkbox and select a signal of your interest from the “Anchor” dropdown menu (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Check all the input details from the side panel and click the “Submit” button.
Note: The run time of the application will depend on the number of files to be analyzed. Processing each of the user’s uploaded signal files may take a few minutes. In our testing with 10 files from the database and 1 user uploaded signal file, it takes 1.5 min to process.
Investigating the correlation of signals at the selected genomic regions
Timing: minutes to hours

Different genomic regions can show different colocalization of the same set of proteins depending on their functional roles. This section describes steps to select different functional regions of the same or different sets of proteins from the database.
Assess the correlation heatmap.
Hover the cursor across the heatmap for exact values of the correlation (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2568-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Screenshot of PAD2 result page
(A) Pearson’s correlation heatmap is shown at the centre of the page. The dendrogram shows the clustering of signals based on their correlation. The labels in both axes are colored by file categories.
(B) Ranked correlation of all the similar groups of proteins to the selected anchor protein.
Hover over the plot and click the disk-shaped icon at the top right corner to download a correlation matrix as CSV file.
Zoom or pan across the heatmap to investigate specific regions of the cluster.
To investigate other genomic regions, select different regions from the dropdown menu in the sidebar panel.
To investigate a different set of signals, repeat from the second step of major step 1 from the result page.
Use the side panel to add any additional files or changes to your parameters to re-analyze.
Select different genomic regions.
If “Plot ranked correlation” was checked from major step 2, scroll down to investigate the ranked correlation plot (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B) of all the similar groups of proteins including the user’s uploaded data.
Optional: Additional user’s input data can be uploaded by clicking the Browse button similarly to point 5 of step 2.
Note: Similar to step 2, one additional signal file upload takes 1.5 min to process.
Downloading your analysis plots
Timing: <1 min
This section describes steps to save your analysis into a vector image.
Download your heatmap plot.

Click the camera icon at the top right corner of the heatmap to download a vector image (SVG) file of the plot.
Choose the location of your local folder to save the image, then click download.
Download your ranked correlation plot.
Click the camera icon at the top right corner of the scatter plot to download a vector image (SVG) file of the plot.
Choose the location of your local folder to save the image, then click download.
